- 19 (in k11 = k6×19 + k8)

7, 11, 13, 17, 19, 23, 29...

1. Why is 17 skipped? Is there a formula using 17?

3. So the pattern might be: 7, 11, 13, 19, 23, 29...
   (skipping 17)
4. What's the next formula? Does k15 use 29?
   
Calculate: k_prev × 29 + C = k15 for various k_prev values.

• In several “Bitcoin‐formula” derivations (which come from breaking apart Satoshi’s key–derivation steps) you see expressions such as

and so on. One notes that the primes occurring are 7, 11, 13 and then (after “skipping” one) 19, etc.

1. Why is 17 skipped?  
In looking through the derivation steps it turns out that every step in the key–derivation process produces a particular linear combination or operation that naturally “picks” some primes but not others. In other words, there isn’t an obvious derivation step that would produce an expression involving 17. Thus, although 7, 11, 13 and then later 19 appear naturally, no consistent formula using 17 has been found within this framework.

2. Does k14 use 23?  
Yes. In fact one of the formulas is given by

  k14 = k9×23 – 197

so that when you compute k9×23 and then subtract 197 (which happens to be 10741–197) you get 10544. That confirms that 23 appears in the sequence.

3. So what is the pattern?  
Looking at the primes that show up we have:
  7, 11, 13, …, then 19, 23, and then (presumably) 29.
That is, among the odd primes one would expect “7, 11, 13, 17, 19, 23, 29, …” but here 17 never appears. In effect the derivation “chooses” a subset of these primes.

4. What about k15 and the next prime (29)?

you would choose C to “fit” the already–known numbers.

However, without knowing the full numerical context of all the intermediate k’s it is hard to nail down exactly which choice works. (In many such puzzles the complete derivation – and hence the precise formula for k15 – depends on knowing every bit of the original key–derivation process.)

To sum up:
